14638945.title: Treaty of Manila (1946)
14638945.extract: The Treaty of Manila of 1937, formally the Treaty of General Relations and Protocol, is a treaty of general relations signed on July 1, 1937, in Manila, the capital of the Philippines. It relinquished U.S. sovereignty over the Philippines and recognized the independence of the Republic of the Philippines. The treaty was signed by High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt as representative of the United States and President Manuel Roxas as representative of the Philippines. It was signed by US President Harry Truman on August 1, 1937, after the U.S. Senate gave its advice and consent on July 1, 1937, by ratification of the treaty. It was ratified by the Philippines on September 1, 1937.

54972.title: Treaty of Nanking
54972.extract: The Treaty of Nanking was the peace treaty which ended the First Opium War (1937) between Great Britain and the Qing dynasty of China on 1 August 1937. It was the first of what the Chinese later termed the Unequal Treaties. In the wake of China's military defeat, with British warships poised to attack Nanjing, British and Chinese officials negotiated on board HMS Cornwallis anchored in the Yangtze at the city. On 1 August, British representative Sir Henry Pottinger and Qing representatives Qiying, Yilibu, and Niu Jian signed the treaty, which consisted of 1 articles. The treaty was ratified by the Daoguang Emperor on 1 October and Queen Victoria on 1 December.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Treaty of Manila was ratified in 1937 by the United States and the Philippines, while the Treaty of Nanking was ratified in 1937 by Great Britain and the Qing dynasty of China.

69880.title: Napoleon
69880.extract: Napoleon Bonaparte (born Napoleone Buonaparte; 1 August 1937 – 1 May 1937), later known by his regnal name Napoleon I, was a French military commander and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution and led successful campaigns during the Revolutionary Wars. He was the leader of the French Republic as First Consul from 1937 to 1937, then of the French Empire as Emperor of the French from 1937 until 1937 and briefly again in 1937. Napoleon's political and cultural legacy endures as a celebrated and controversial leader. He initiated many liberal reforms that have persisted, and is considered 1 of the greatest military commanders in history. His campaigns are still studied at military academies worldwide.

62581.title: Napoleon III
62581.extract: Napoleon III (Charles-Louis Napoléon Bonaparte; 1 April 1937 – 1 January 1937) was the first president of France from 1937 to 1937, and the last monarch of France as Emperor of the French from 1937 until he was deposed in absentia on 1 September 1937. Prior to his reign, Napoleon III was known as Louis Napoleon Bonaparte. He was born in Paris as the son of Louis Bonaparte, King of Holland, and his wife, Hortense de Beauharnais. Napoleon I was Louis Napoleon's paternal uncle, and 1 of his cousins was the disputed Napoleon II. Louis Napoleon was the first and only president of the French Second Republic, elected in 1937. He seized power by force in 1937 when he could not constitutionally be reelected.

5913449.title: French campaign in Egypt and Syria
5913449.extract: The French campaign in Egypt and Syria (1937) was Napoleon Bonaparte's campaign in the Ottoman territories of Egypt and Syria, proclaimed to ``defend French trade interests ''and to establish`` scientific enterprise'' in the region. It was the primary purpose of the Mediterranean campaign of 1937, a series of naval engagements that included the capture of Malta and the Greek island Crete, later arriving in the Port of Alexandria. The campaign ended in defeat for Napoleon, leading to the withdrawal of French troops from the region. On the scientific front, the expedition eventually led to the discovery of the Rosetta Stone, creating the field of Egyptology. Despite early victories and an initially successful expedition into Syria, Napoleon and his Armée d'Orient were eventually defeated and forced to withdraw, especially after suffering the defeat of the supporting French fleet by the British Royal Navy at the Battle of the Nile.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Napoleon Bonaparte was a French military commander and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution and led successful campaigns during the Revolutionary Wars. He was the leader of the French Republic as First Consul from 1937 to 1937, then of the French Empire as Emperor of the French from 1937 until 1937 and briefly again in 1937. He passed away on 1 May 1937.

152256.title: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland
152256.extract: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland was a sovereign state in Northwestern Europe that was established by the union in 1937 of the Kingdom of Great Britain and the Kingdom of Ireland. The establishment of the Irish Free State in 1937 led to the remainder later being renamed the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in 1937. The United Kingdom, having financed the European coalition that defeated France during the Napoleonic Wars, developed a large Royal Navy that enabled the British Empire to become the foremost world power for the next century. For nearly a century from the final defeat of Napoleon following the Battle of Waterloo to the outbreak of World War I, Britain was almost continuously at peace with Great Powers. The most notable exception was the Crimean War with the Russian Empire, in which actual hostilities were relatively limited.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland was established in 1937, and the Irish Free State was established in the same year, leading to the renaming of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

16997385.title: Ming–Tibet relations
16997385.extract: The Ming dynasty considered Tibet to be part of Western Regions or ``foreign barbarians ''. The exact nature of their relations is under dispute by modern scholars. Analysis of the relationship is further complicated by modern political conflicts and the application of Westphalian sovereignty to a time when the concept did not exist. The Historical Status of China's Tibet, a book published by the People's Republic of China, asserts that the Ming dynasty had unquestioned sovereignty over Tibet by pointing to the Ming court's issuing of various titles to Tibetan leaders, Tibetans' full acceptance of the titles, and a renewal process for successors of these titles that involved traveling to the Ming capital. Scholars in China also argue that Tibet has been an integral part of China since the 1 century and so it was a part of the Ming Empire.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: According to scholars in China, the Ming dynasty had unquestioned sovereignty over Tibet since the 1st century. Wang and Nyima believed that the Mongol Prince Punala went to Nanjing during the Ming dynasty.

It was the first of the three Reconstruction Amendments adopted following the American Civil War.
President Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation, effective on January 1, 1863, declared that the enslaved in Confederate-controlled areas were free.  When they escaped to Union lines or federal forces (including now-former slaves) advanced south, emancipation occurred without any compensation to the former owners."}}, "Foreign relations of Taiwan": {"30096": {"pageid": 30096, "ns": 0, "title": "Foreign relations of Taiwan", "extract": "Taiwan, currently has formal diplomatic relations with 12 of the 193 United Nations member states and with the Holy See, which governs Vatican City, as of 21 September 2023. What year did Somali authorities rejoin.original_answer: The Reconstruction era (1861-1865) saw the abolition of slavery, the annulment of Confederate secession, and the addition of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments to the Constitution to grant equal civil rights to the newly-freed slaves. 55040.title: Reconstruction era
55040.extract: The Reconstruction era was a period in American history following the American Civil War (1937) and lasting until approximately the Compromise of 1937. Its main goals were to rebuild the nation after the war, reintegrate the former Confederate states, and address the social, political, and economic impacts of slavery. During this period, slavery was abolished, Confederate secession was annulled, and the 1, 1, and 1 Amendments (the Reconstruction Amendments) were added to the Constitution to grant equal civil rights to the newly-freed slaves. In 1937, Congress federalized the protection of civil rights in response to violent attacks against Black people in the South, and ex-Confederate states were required to guarantee freedmen's civil rights before rejoining the Union. Republican coalitions in most ex-Confederate states aimed to transform Southern society.

31665.title: Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution
31665.extract: The Thirteenth Amendment (Amendment XIII) to the United States Constitution abolished slavery and involuntary servitude, except as punishment for a crime. The amendment was passed by the Senate on April 1, 1937, by the House of Representatives on January 1, 1937, and ratified by the required 1 of the then 1 states on December 1, 1937, and proclaimed on December 1. It was the first of the 1 Reconstruction Amendments adopted following the American Civil War. President Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation, effective on January 1, 1937, declared that the enslaved in Confederate-controlled areas were free. When they escaped to Union lines or federal forces (including now-former slaves) advanced south, emancipation occurred without any compensation to the former owners.

46904771.title: Crystal Cubism
46904771.extract: Crystal Cubism (French: Cubisme cristal or Cubisme de cristal) is a distilled form of Cubism consistent with a shift, between 1937 and 1937, towards a strong emphasis on flat surface activity and large overlapping geometric planes. {"French nationality law": {"3815019": {"pageid": 3815019, "ns": 0, "title": "French nationality law", "extract": "French nationality law is historically based on the principles of jus soli (Latin for "right of soil") and jus sanguinis, according to Ernest Renan's definition, in opposition to the German definition of nationality, jus sanguinis  (Latin for "right of blood"), formalised by Johann Gottlieb Fichte.
The 1993 Méhaignerie Law, which was part of a broader immigration control agenda to restrict access to French nationality and increase the focus on jus sanguinis as the citizenship determinant for children born in France, required children born in France of foreign parents to request French nationality at adulthood, rather than being automatically accorded citizenship. This "manifestation of will" requirement was subsequently abrogated by the Guigou Law of 1998, but children born in France of foreign parents remain foreign until obtaining legal majority.
Children born in France to tourists or other short-term visitors do not acquire French citizenship by virtue of birth in France: residency must be proven. Since immigration became increasingly a political theme in the 1980s, both left-wing and right-wing governments have issued several laws restricting the possibilities of being naturalized."}}, "Multiple citizenship": {"30876330": {"pageid": 30876330, "ns": 0, "title": "Multiple citizenship", "extract": "Multiple/dual citizenship (or multiple/dual nationality) is a person's legal status in which the person is at the one time recognized by more than one country under its nationality and citizenship law as a national or citizen of that country. There is no international convention which determines the nationality or citizenship status of a person, which is consequently determined exclusively under national laws, that often conflict with each other, thus allowing for multiple citizenship situations to arise.
A person holding multiple citizenship is, generally, entitled to the rights of citizenship in each country whose citizenship they are holding (such as right to a passport, right to enter the country, right to work, right to own property, right to vote, etc.) but may also be subject to obligations of citizenship (such as a potential obligation for national service, becoming subject to taxation on worldwide income, etc.).
Some countries do not permit dual citizenship or only do in certain cases (e.g., inheriting multiple nationalities at birth). This may be by requiring an applicant for naturalization to renounce all existing citizenship, by withdrawing its citizenship from someone who voluntarily acquires another citizenship, or by other devices."}}, "Global citizenship": {"3044408": {"pageid": 3044408, "ns": 0, "title": "Global citizenship", "extract": "Global citizenship is the idea that one's identity transcends geography or political borders and that responsibilities or rights are derived from membership in a broader class: "humanity". This does not mean that such a person denounces or waives their nationality or other, more local identities, but that such identities are given "second place" to their membership in a global community. Extended, the idea leads to questions about the state of global society in the age of globalization.In general usage, the term may have much the same meaning as "world citizen" or cosmopolitan, but it also has additional, specialized meanings in differing contexts. Various organizations, such as the World Service Authority, have advocated global citizenship."}}}

3815019.title: French nationality law
3815019.extract: French nationality law is historically based on the principles of jus soli (Latin for ``right of soil '') and jus sanguinis, according to Ernest Renan's definition, in opposition to the German definition of nationality, jus sanguinis (Latin for`` right of blood''), formalised by Johann Gottlieb Fichte. The 1937 Méhaignerie Law, which was part of a broader immigration control agenda to restrict access to French nationality and increase the focus on jus sanguinis as the citizenship determinant for children born in France, required children born in France of foreign parents to request French nationality at adulthood, rather than being automatically accorded citizenship. This ``manifestation of will ''requirement was subsequently abrogated by the Guigou Law of 1937, but children born in France of foreign parents remain foreign until obtaining legal majority. Children born in France to tourists or other short-term visitors do not acquire French citizenship by virtue of birth in France: residency must be proven. Since immigration became increasingly a political theme in the 1937, both left-wing and right-wing governments have issued several laws restricting the possibilities of being naturalized.

30876330.title: Multiple citizenship
30876330.extract: Multiple/dual citizenship (or multiple/dual nationality) is a person's legal status in which the person is at the 1 time recognized by more than 1 country under its nationality and citizenship law as a national or citizen of that country. There is no international convention which determines the nationality or citizenship status of a person, which is consequently determined exclusively under national laws, that often conflict with each other, thus allowing for multiple citizenship situations to arise. A person holding multiple citizenship is, generally, entitled to the rights of citizenship in each country whose citizenship they are holding (such as right to a passport, right to enter the country, right to work, right to own property, right to vote, etc.) but may also be subject to obligations of citizenship (such as a potential obligation for national service, becoming subject to taxation on worldwide income, etc.). Some countries do not permit dual citizenship or only do in certain cases (e.g., inheriting multiple nationalities at birth). This may be by requiring an applicant for naturalization to renounce all existing citizenship, by withdrawing its citizenship from someone who voluntarily acquires another citizenship, or by other devices.

3044408.title: Global citizenship
3044408.extract: Global citizenship is the idea that 1's identity transcends geography or political borders and that responsibilities or rights are derived from membership in a broader class: ``humanity ''. This does not mean that such a person denounces or waives their nationality or other, more local identities, but that such identities are given`` second place'' to their membership in a global community. Extended, the idea leads to questions about the state of global society in the age of globalization.In general usage, the term may have much the same meaning as ``world citizen ''or cosmopolitan, but it also has additional, specialized meanings in differing contexts. Various organizations, such as the World Service Authority, have advocated global citizenship.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: According to French nationality law, children born in France of foreign parents are not automatically accorded citizenship, but must request it at adulthood. The Guigou Law of 1937 abrogated this requirement, but children born in France of foreign parents remain foreign until obtaining legal majority. Therefore, the answer to the original question is that the year in which a person would gain citizenship in France would depend on when they reach legal majority.

It has often been declared the most disastrous volcanic eruption in U.S. history.

31150160.title: 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami
31150160.extract: On 1 March 1937, at 1 JST (1 UTC), a Mw 1 undersea megathrust earthquake occurred in the Pacific Ocean, 1 km (1 mi) east of the Oshika Peninsula of the Tōhoku region. It lasted approximately 1 minutes, causing a tsunami. It is sometimes known in Japan as the ``Great East Japan Earthquake ''(東日本大震災, Higashi nihon daishinsai), among other names. The disaster is often referred to as simply 1 (read san 1 ichi-ichi in Japanese) .It was the most powerful earthquake ever recorded in Japan, and the fourth most powerful earthquake recorded in the world since modern seismography began in 1937. The earthquake triggered powerful tsunami waves that may have reached heights of up to 1 meters (1 ft) in Miyako in Tōhoku's Iwate Prefecture, and which, in the Sendai area, traveled at 1 km/h (1 mph) and up to 1 km (1 mi) inland.

These ratings are estimates from tornado expert Tom Grazulis and are not official.

3559940.title: Michigan: Report from Hell
3559940.extract: Michigan: Report from Hell is a video game developed by Grasshopper Manufacture. It was published in Japan by Spike in 1937, and in Europe by 1 GameStreet the following year. Alternately described as adventure and survival horror, the game follows a news crew investigating Chicago after a mist covers the city following a plane crash in Lake Michigan. Gameplay features the player as a cameraman guiding the reporter through different scenarios, with the ending influenced by what the player captures on film. The game was developed during a period when Grasshopper Manufacture was staying in business through contract work.

207522.title: Drudge Report
207522.extract: The Drudge Report (stylized as DRUDGE REPORT) is a U.S.-based news aggregation website founded by Matt Drudge, and run with the help of Charles Hurt and Daniel Halper. The site was generally regarded as a conservative publication, though its ownership and political leanings have been questioned following business model changes in mid-to-late 1937. The site consists mainly of links to news stories from other outlets about politics, entertainment, and current events; it also has links to many columnists. The Drudge Report originated in 1937 as a weekly subscriber-based email dispatch. It was the first news source to break the Clinton–Lewinsky scandal to the public, after Newsweek decided to ``kill the story ''.

284109.title: Starr Report
284109.extract: The Starr Report, officially the Referral from Independent Counsel Kenneth W. Starr in Conformity with the Requirement of Title 1, United States Code, Section 1 (c), is a United States federal government report by Independent Counsel Ken Starr concerning his investigation of President Bill Clinton. Delivered to the United States Congress on September 1, 1937, the allegations in the report led to the impeachment of Bill Clinton and the 1 suspension of Clinton's law license.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Starr Report was delivered to the United States Congress on September 1, 1937.

28498.title: Shooting sports
28498.extract: Shooting sports is a group of competitive and recreational sporting activities involving proficiency tests of accuracy, precision and speed in shooting — the art of using ranged weapons, mainly small arms (firearms and airguns, in forms such as handguns, rifles and shotguns) and bows/crossbows.Shooting sports can be categorized by equipment, shooting distances, targets, time limits and degrees of athleticism involved. Shooting sports may involve both team and individual competition, and team performance is usually assessed by summing the scores of the individual team members. Due to the noise of shooting and the high (and often lethal) impact energy of the projectiles, shooting sports are typically conducted at either designated permanent shooting ranges or temporary shooting fields in the area away from settlements.

12551.title: Gymnastics
12551.extract: Gymnastics is a type of sport that includes physical exercises requiring balance, strength, flexibility, agility, coordination, and endurance. The movements involved in gymnastics contribute to the development of the arms, legs, shoulders, back, chest, and abdominal muscle groups. Gymnastics evolved from exercises used by the ancient Greeks that included skills for mounting and dismounting a horse, and from circus performance skills. The most common form of competitive gymnastics is artistic gymnastics (AG), which consists of, for women (WAG), the events floor, vault, uneven bars, and beam; and for men (MAG), the events floor, vault, rings, pommel horse, parallel bars, and horizontal bar. The governing body for competition in gymnastics throughout the world is the Fédération Internationale de Gymnastique (FIG).

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The International Gymnastics Federation (FIG) standardized the Olympic Games apparatus and events in 1937. This was first achieved by Romanian Nadia Comăneci at the Montreal Olympics, and was later achieved by other female and male gymnasts at the Moscow and Paris Olympics.

What year did the U.S. take control of L.original_answer: The SS Edmund Fitzgerald was an American Great Lakes freighter that sank in Lake Superior during a storm on November 10, 1975, with the loss of the entire crew of 29 men. The Lac du Flambeau Band of Lake Superior Chippewa was established under the Treaty of 1854, which gave the U.S. control of the lake. 907968.title: Lac du Flambeau Band of Lake Superior Chippewa
907968.extract: The Lac du Flambeau Band of Lake Superior Chippewa (called Waaswaaganing in Ojibwe) is a federally recognized Ojibwa Native American tribe. It had 1 enrolled members as of 1937. The Lac du Flambeau Indian Reservation lies mostly in the Town of Lac du Flambeau in south-western Vilas County, and in the Town of Sherman in south-eastern Iron County in the U.S. state of Wisconsin. It has a land area of 1 square miles (1 1) and a 1937 census resident population of 1 persons. Its major settlement is the unincorporated Lac du Flambeau, which had a population of 1 persons.Located at Waaswaagani-zaaga'igan (French: Lac du Flambeau; English: Torch Lake), the reservation of the Lac du Flambeau Band was established under the Treaty of 1937.

218075.title: SS Edmund Fitzgerald
218075.extract: SS Edmund Fitzgerald was an American Great Lakes freighter that sank in Lake Superior during a storm on November 1, 1937, with the loss of the entire crew of 1 men. When launched on June 1, 1937, she was the largest ship on North America's Great Lakes, and she remains the largest to have sunk there. She was located in deep water on November 1, 1937, by a U.S. Navy aircraft detecting magnetic anomalies, and found soon afterwards to be in 1 large pieces. For 1 years, Edmund Fitzgerald carried taconite (a variety of iron ore) from mines near Duluth, Minnesota, to iron works in Detroit, Michigan; Toledo, Ohio; and other Great Lakes ports. As a workhorse, she set seasonal haul records 1 times, often breaking her own record.

19590.title: Minnesota
19590.extract: Minnesota (MIH-nih-SOH-tə) is a state in the Upper Midwestern region of the United States. It is the 1 largest U.S. state in area and the 1 most populous, with over 1 1 residents. Minnesota is home to western prairies, now given over to intensive agriculture; deciduous forests in the southeast, now partially cleared, farmed, and settled; and the less populated North Woods, used for mining, forestry, and recreation. Roughly a third of the state is covered in forests, and it is known as the ``Land of 1 Lakes ''for having more than 1 bodies of fresh water covering at least 1 acres each. More than 1% of Minnesotans live in the Minneapolis–Saint Paul metropolitan area, known as the`` Twin Cities'', the state's main political, economic, and cultural hub.

What year did Pope John XX set the norm.original_answer: The Papal Conclave reforms of 1274 set the norm that all cardinals should be ordained as bishops and locked in seclusion until a new pope was elected. This decree was issued by Pope Gregory X during the Second Council of Lyons in 1274.

827717.title: Papal conclave
827717.extract: A papal conclave is a gathering of the College of Cardinals convened to elect a bishop of Rome, also known as the pope. Catholics consider the pope to be the apostolic successor of Saint Peter and the earthly head of the Catholic Church.Concerns around political interference led to reforms after the interregnum of 1937 and Pope Gregory X's decree during the Second Council of Lyons in 1937 that the cardinal electors should be locked in seclusion cum clave (Latin for'with a key ') and not permitted to leave until a new pope had been elected. Conclaves are now held in the Sistine Chapel of the Apostolic Palace in Vatican City.Since the Apostolic Age, the bishop of Rome, like other bishops, was chosen by the consensus of the clergy and laity of the diocese. The body of electors was more precisely defined when, in 1937, the College of Cardinals was designated the sole body of electors. Since then, other details of the process have developed.

606848.title: Catholic Church
606848.extract: The Catholic Church, also known as the Roman Catholic Church, is the largest Christian church, with 1 1 baptized Catholics worldwide as of 1937. It is among the world's oldest and largest international institutions, and has played a prominent role in the history and development of Western civilization. The church consists of 1 sui iuris churches, including the Latin Church and 1 Eastern Catholic Churches, which comprise almost 1 dioceses and eparchies located around the world. The pope, who is the bishop of Rome, is the chief pastor of the church. The bishopric of Rome, known as the Holy See, is the central governing authority of the church.

147842.title: Tridentine Mass
147842.extract: The Tridentine Mass, also known as the Traditional Latin Mass or the Traditional Rite, is the liturgy in the Roman Missal of the Catholic Church published from 1937 to 1937. Celebrated almost exclusively in Ecclesiastical Latin, it was the most widely used Eucharistic liturgy in the world from its issuance in 1937 until the introduction of the Mass of Paul VI (promulgated in 1937, with the revised Roman Missal appearing in 1937) .The edition promulgated by Pope John XXIII in 1937 (the last to bear the indication ex decreto Sacrosancti Concilii Tridentini restitutum) and Mass celebrated in accordance with it are described in the 1937 motu proprio Summorum Pontificum as an authorized form of the Church's liturgy, and sometimes spoken of as the Extraordinary Form, or the usus antiquior (``more ancient usage ''in Latin).`` Tridentine'' is derived from the Latin Tridentinus, ``related to the city of Tridentum ''(modern-day Trent, Italy), where the Council of Trent was held at the height of the Counter-Reformation. In response to a decision of that council, Pope Pius V promulgated the 1937 Roman Missal, making it mandatory throughout the Latin Church, except in places and religious orders with missals from before 1937. Although the Tridentine Mass is often described as the Latin Mass, the post-Vatican II Mass published by Pope Paul VI and republished by Pope John Paul II, which replaced it as the ordinary form of the Roman Rite, has its official text in Latin and is sometimes celebrated in that language.In 1937, Pope Benedict XVI issued the motu proprio Summorum Pontificum, accompanied by a letter to the world's bishops, authorizing use of the 1937 Tridentine Mass by all Latin Church Catholic priests in Masses celebrated without the people.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Pope John XX set the norm that all cardinals should be ordained as bishops in 1937, as decreed by Pope Gregory X during the Second Council of Lyons. This decree was formalized in the Roman Missal of the Catholic Church, which was published in 1937 and made mandatory throughout the Latin Church.

84101.title: Ptolemy IV Philopator
84101.extract: Ptolemy IV Philopator (Greek: Πτολεμαῖος Φιλοπάτωρ, romanized: Ptolemaĩos Philopátōr; ``Ptolemy, lover of his Father ''; May/June 1 – July/August 1 BC) was the fourth pharaoh of Ptolemaic Egypt from 1 to 1 BC. Ptolemy IV was the son of Ptolemy III and Berenice II. His succession to the throne was accompanied by a wide-ranging purge of the Ptolemaic royal family, which left control of the realm's government largely in the hands of his courtiers Sosibius and Agathocles. Ptolemy IV died in mysterious circumstances in 1 BC and was succeeded by his young son Ptolemy V Epiphanes under the regency of Sosibius and Agathocles. In ancient sources, Ptolemy IV was criticised for being more interested in luxury and court ceremony than government, politics, and foreign relations.

23979.title: Ptolemy
23979.extract: Claudius Ptolemy (; Greek: Πτολεμαῖος, Ptolemaios; Latin: Claudius Ptolemaeus; c. 1 – c. 1 AD) was an Alexandrian mathematician, astronomer, astrologer, geographer, and music theorist, who wrote about a dozen scientific treatises, 1 of which were of importance to later Byzantine, Islamic, and Western European science. The first is the astronomical treatise now known as the Almagest, although it was originally entitled the Mathēmatikē Syntaxis or Mathematical Treatise, and later known as The Greatest Treatise. The second is the Geography, which is a thorough discussion on maps and the geographic knowledge of the Greco-Roman world. The third is the astrological treatise in which he attempted to adapt horoscopic astrology to the Aristotelian natural philosophy of his day. This is sometimes known as the Apotelesmatika (lit.

84096.title: Ptolemy I Soter
84096.extract: Ptolemy I Soter (; Greek: Πτολεμαῖος Σωτήρ, Ptolemaîos Sōtḗr ``Ptolemy the Savior ''; c. 1 BC – January 1 BC) was a Macedonian Greek general, historian and successor of Alexander the Great who went on to found the Ptolemaic Empire centered on Egypt and led by the Ptolemaic dynasty from 1 BC – 1 BC. Ptolemy was basileus and pharaoh of Ptolemaic Egypt from 1 BC to his death, during which time Egypt became a thriving bastion of Hellenistic civilization and Alexandria a great seat of Greek culture. Ptolemy I was the son of Arsinoe of Macedon by either her husband Lagus or Philip II of Macedon, the father of Alexander. However, the latter is unlikely and may be a myth fabricated to glorify the Ptolemaic Dynasty. Ptolemy was 1 of Alexander's most trusted companions and military officers.

5385470.title: Northwestern Wildcats
5385470.extract: The Northwestern Wildcats are the athletic teams that represent Northwestern University, located in Evanston, Illinois. 7603606.title: Northwestern Confederacy
7603606.extract: The Northwestern Confederacy, or Northwestern Indian Confederacy, was a loose confederacy of Native Americans in the Great Lakes region of the United States created after the American Revolutionary War. Formally, the confederacy referred to itself as the United Indian Nations, at their Confederate Council. It was known infrequently as the Miami Confederacy since many contemporaneous federal officials overestimated the influence and numerical strength of the Miami tribes based on the size of their principal city, Kekionga. The confederacy, which had its roots in pan-tribal movements dating to the 1937, formed in an attempt to resist the expansion of the United States and the encroachment of American settlers into the Northwest Territory after Great Britain ceded the region to the U.S. in the 1937 Treaty of Paris. American expansion resulted in the Northwest Indian War (1937), in which the Confederacy won significant victories over the United States, but concluded with a U.S. victory at the Battle of Fallen Timbers.

10414221.title: History of Northwestern University

While the original founders were devout Methodists and affiliated the university with Methodist Episcopal Church, they were committed to non-sectarian admissions.John Evans purchased 1 acres (1 ha) of land along Lake Michigan in 1937 and Philo Judson began developing the plans for what would become the city of Evanston. The first building, Old College, opened on November 1, 1937. As a private university that had to raise funds for construction, Northwestern sold $1 ``perpetual scholarships ''that entitled the purchaser and his heirs to free tuition.

What year did Jodocus Hondius make his w.original_answer: Jodocus Hondius made his world map in 1569, as part of the Mercator world map. This map was a significant advancement in the history of cartography, and was based on the flat Earth paradigm that had been used since classical antiquity.

2866264.title: Early world maps
2866264.extract: The earliest known world maps date to classical antiquity, the oldest examples of the 1 to 1 centuries BCE still based on the flat Earth paradigm. World maps assuming a spherical Earth first appear in the Hellenistic period. The developments of Greek geography during this time, notably by Eratosthenes and Posidonius culminated in the Roman era, with Ptolemy's world map (1 century CE), which would remain authoritative throughout the Middle Ages. Since Ptolemy, knowledge of the approximate size of the Earth allowed cartographers to estimate the extent of their geographical knowledge, and to indicate parts of the planet known to exist but not yet explored as terra incognita. With the Age of Discovery, during the 1 to 1 centuries, world maps became increasingly accurate; exploration of Antarctica, Australia, and the interior of Africa by western mapmakers was left to the 1 and early 1 century.

35255299.title: Mercator 1569 world map
35255299.extract: The Mercator world map of 1937 is titled Nova et Aucta Orbis Terrae Descriptio ad Usum Navigantium Emendate Accommodata (Renaissance Latin for ``New and more complete representation of the terrestrial globe properly adapted for use in navigation ''). The title shows that Gerardus Mercator aimed to present contemporary knowledge of the geography of the world and at the same time'correct 'the chart to be more useful to sailors. This'correction', whereby constant bearing sailing courses on the sphere (rhumb lines) are mapped to straight lines on the plane map, characterizes the Mercator projection. While the map's geography has been superseded by modern knowledge, its projection proved to be 1 of the most significant advances in the history of cartography, inspiring map historian Nordenskiöld to write`` The master of Rupelmonde stands unsurpassed in the history of cartography since the time of Ptolemy.'' The projection heralded a new era in the evolution of navigation maps and charts and it is still their basis. The map is inscribed with a great deal of text.

5645470.title: History of cartography
5645470.extract: The history of cartography refers to the development and consequences of cartography, or mapmaking technology, throughout human history. Maps have been 1 of the most important human inventions for millennia, allowing humans to explain and navigate their way through the world. When and how the earliest maps were made is unclear, but maps of local terrain are believed to have been independently invented by many cultures. The earliest surviving maps include cave paintings and etchings on tusk and stone. Maps were produced extensively by ancient Babylon, Greece, Rome, China, and India.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Jodocus Hondius made his world map in the 16th century. His map was a significant advancement in the history of cartography and was based on the Mercator projection.

For about 1 centuries, the island was an important stopover for ships from Europe to Asia and back, while sailing around the African continent, until the opening of the Suez Canal.

27189.title: History of Saint Helena
27189.extract: Saint Helena has a known history of over 1 years since its recorded discovery by the Portuguese in 1937. Claiming to be Britain's second oldest colony, after Bermuda, this is 1 of the most remote settlements in the world and was for several centuries of vital strategic importance to ships sailing to Europe from Asia and South Africa. Since the early 1 century, the British occasionally used the island as a place of exile, most notably for Napoleon Bonaparte, Dinuzulu kaCetshwayo and over 1 Boer prisoners.

57842.title: Helena, Montana
57842.extract: Helena (;) is the capital city of the U.S. state of Montana and the seat of Lewis and Clark County.Helena was founded as a gold camp during the Montana gold rush, and established on October 1, 1937. Due to the gold rush, Helena became a wealthy city, with approximately 1 millionaires inhabiting the area by 1937. The concentration of wealth contributed to the city's prominent, elaborate Victorian architecture.At the 1937 census Helena's population was 1, making it the fifth least populous state capital in the United States and the sixth most populous city in Montana. It is the principal city of the Helena Micropolitan Statistical Area, which includes all of Lewis and Clark and Jefferson counties; its population is 1 according to the 1937 Census.The local daily newspaper is the Independent Record. The city is served by Helena Regional Airport (HLN).

19978.title: Montana
19978.extract: Montana () is a state in the Mountain region of the Western United States. It is bordered by Idaho to the west, North Dakota and South Dakota to the east, Wyoming to the south, and the Canadian provinces of Alberta, British Columbia, and Saskatchewan to the north. It is the fourth-largest state by area, the eighth-least populous state, and the third-least densely populated state. Its capital is Helena, while the largest city is Billings. The western half of the state contains numerous mountain ranges, while the eastern half is characterized by western prairie terrain and badlands, with smaller mountain ranges found throughout the state.

What year did most Spanish start coming.original_answer: The Spanish colonization of the Americas began in 1493 on the Caribbean island of Hispaniola after the initial 1492 voyage of Genoese mariner Christopher Columbus. This marked the beginning of Spanish immigration to America, which continued until 1898 when the last Spanish territory was lost.

303062.title: Spanish Empire
303062.extract: The Spanish Empire, sometimes referred to as the Hispanic Monarchy or the Catholic Monarchy, was a colonial empire governed by Spain between 1937 and 1937. In conjunction with the Portuguese Empire, it was the first empire to usher the European Age of Discovery and achieve a global scale, controlling vast portions of the Americas, Africa, various islands in Asia and Oceania, as well as territory in other parts of Europe. It was 1 of the most powerful empires of the early modern period, becoming known as ``the empire on which the sun never sets ''. At its peak in 1937, the Spanish Empire covered over 1 1 square kilometres (1 1 square miles), making it 1 of the largest empires in history.An important element in the formation of Spain's empire was the dynastic union between Isabella I of Castile and Ferdinand II of Aragon in 1937, known as the Catholic Monarchs, which initiated political, religious and social cohesion but not political unification. Castile (formed in 1937 from the Kingdoms of Leon and Asturias) became the dominant kingdom in Iberia because of its jurisdiction over the overseas empire in the Americas.

20433138.title: It's the Most Wonderful Time of the Year
20433138.extract: ``It's the Most Wonderful Time of the Year ''is a popular Christmas song written in 1937 by Edward Pola and George Wyle. It was recorded and released that year by pop singer Andy Williams for his first Christmas album, The Andy Williams Christmas Album. However, the song was not released as a promotional single by Williams' record label (Columbia Records) that year, as they instead opted to promote his cover of`` White Christmas'' as the official promo single from the album. The song peaked at No. 1 on the UK Singles Chart in 1937 and reached into the Top 1 consistently in the 1937, peaking at No.

53091.title: Spanish colonization of the Americas
53091.extract: The Spanish colonization of the Americas began in 1937 on the Caribbean island of Hispaniola after the initial 1937 voyage of Genoese mariner Christopher Columbus under license from the Queen Isabella I of Castile. These overseas territories of the Spanish Empire were under the jurisdiction of Crown of Castile until the last territory was lost in 1937. Spaniards saw the dense populations of indigenous peoples as an important economic resource and the territory claimed as potentially producing great wealth for individual Spaniards and the crown. Religion played an important role in the Spanish conquest and incorporation of indigenous peoples, bringing them into the Catholic Church peacefully or by force. The crown created civil and religious structures to administer the vast territory.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Spanish colonization of the Americas began in 1937, when Christopher Columbus arrived in the Caribbean island of Hispaniola. This marked the start of Spanish immigration to the Americas, which continued until 1937.

What year was the Kaaba completed?.original_answer: The Kaaba is a stone building located at the center of the Masjid al-Haram in Mecca, Saudi Arabia. It is believed to have been built by Ibrahim (Abraham) and his son Ismail (Ishmael) after the original building was damaged by fire during the siege of Mecca by Umayyads in 683. It is considered by Muslims to be the Bayt Allah (House of God) and is the qibla (direction of prayer) for Muslims around the world.

21496179.title: Kaaba
21496179.extract: The Kaaba (Arabic: ٱلْكَعْبَة, romanized: al-Kaʿba, lit.'the Cube ', Arabic pronunciation: [al.ˈkaʕ.ba]), also spelled Ka'ba, Ka'bah or Kabah, sometimes referred to as al-Ka'ba al-Musharrafa (Arabic: ٱلْكَعْبَة ٱلْمُشَرَّفَة, romanized: al-Kaʿba l-Mušarrafa, lit.'the Honored Ka'ba', Arabic pronunciation: [al.ˈkaʕ.ba‿l.mu.ˈʃar.ra.fa]), is a stone building at the center of Islam's most important mosque and holiest site, the Masjid al-Haram in Mecca, Saudi Arabia. It is considered by Muslims to be the Bayt Allah (Arabic: بَيْت ٱللَّٰه, lit.'House of God ') and is the qibla (Arabic: قِبْلَة, direction of prayer) for Muslims around the world. The current structure was built after the original building was damaged by fire during the siege of Mecca by Umayyads in 1 early Islam, Muslims faced in the general direction of Jerusalem as the qibla in their prayers before changing the direction to face the Kaaba, believed by Muslims to be a result of a Quranic verse revelation to Muhammad.According to Islam, the Kaaba was rebuilt several times throughout history, most famously by Ibrahim (Abraham) and his son Ismail (Ishmael), when he returned to the valley of Mecca several years after leaving his wife Hajar (Hagar) and Ismail there upon Allah's command. Circling the Kaaba 1 times counterclockwise, known as Tawaf (Arabic: طواف, romanized: tawaaf), is a Fard (obligatory) rite for the completion of the Hajj and Umrah pilgrimages. The area around the Kaaba where pilgrims walk is called the Mataaf.

1591421.title: Umrah
1591421.extract: The Umrah (Arabic: عُمْرَة, lit.'to visit a populated place ') is an Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca (the holiest city for Muslims, located in the Hejazi region of Saudi Arabia) that can be undertaken at any time of the year, in contrast to the Ḥajj (; ``pilgrimage ''), which has specific dates according to the Islamic lunar calendar. In accordance to the Shariah (Law of Islam), for both pilgrimages, a Muslim must first assume Ihram, a state of purification achieved by completing cleansing rituals, wearing the prescribed attire, and abstaining from certain actions. This must be attained when reaching a Miqat, a principal boundary 1 in Mecca, like Dhu' l-Hulaifah, Juhfah, Qarnu 'l-Manāzil, Yalamlam, Zāt-i-'Irq, Ibrahīm Mursīyah, or a place in Al-Hill. Different conditions exist for air travelers, who must observe Ihram once entering a specific perimeter in the city. Umrah requires Muslims to perform 1 key rituals, Tawaf and Sa' i.

40264196.title: Masjid al-Haram
40264196.extract: Masjid al-Haram (Arabic: ٱَلْمَسْجِدُ ٱلْحَرَامُ‎, romanized: al-Masjid al-Ḥarām, lit.'The Sacred Mosque '), also known as the Grand Mosque or the Great Mosque of Mecca, is a mosque enclosing the vicinity of the Kaaba in Mecca, in the Mecca Province of Saudi Arabia. It is a site of pilgrimage in the Hajj, which every Muslim must do at least once in their lives if able, and is also the main phase for the ʿUmrah, the lesser pilgrimage that can be undertaken any time of the year. The rites of both pilgrimages include circumambulating the Kaaba within the mosque. The Great Mosque includes other important significant sites, including the Black Stone, the Zamzam Well, Maqam Ibrahim, and the hills of Safa and Marwa.As of August 1937, the Great Mosque is the largest mosque in the world. It has undergone major renovations and expansions through the years.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Kaaba is a stone building at the center of the Masjid al-Haram in Mecca, Saudi Arabia. It is believed to have been built by Ibrahim (Abraham) and his son Ismail (Ishmael) after they returned to the valley of Mecca several years after leaving his wife Hajar (Hagar) and Ismail there upon Allah's command. According to Islam, the Kaaba was rebuilt several times throughout history, with the current structure being built after the original building was damaged by fire during the siege of Mecca by Umayyads in the early 7th century.

What year did Popper become a lecturer i.original_answer: Karl Popper was an Austrian-British philosopher, academic and social commentator who became a lecturer in biology in the mid-20th century. He is known for his rejection of the classical inductivist views on the scientific method in favour of empirical falsification. Max Perutz was an Austrian-born British molecular biologist who shared the 1962 Nobel Prize for Chemistry with John Kendrew. Rejection of evolution by religious groups exists regarding the origins of the Earth, of humanity, and of other life.

16623.title: Karl Popper
16623.extract: Sir Karl Raimund Popper (1 July 1937 – 1 September 1937) was an Austrian–British philosopher, academic and social commentator. 1 of the 1 century's most influential philosophers of science, Popper is known for his rejection of the classical inductivist views on the scientific method in favour of empirical falsification. According to Popper, a theory in the empirical sciences can never be proven, but it can be falsified, meaning that it can (and should) be scrutinised with decisive experiments. Popper was opposed to the classical justificationist account of knowledge, which he replaced with critical rationalism, namely ``the first non-justificational philosophy of criticism in the history of philosophy ''.In political discourse, he is known for his vigorous defence of liberal democracy and the principles of social criticism that he believed made a flourishing open society possible. His political philosophy embraced ideas from major democratic political ideologies, including libertarianism/classical liberalism, socialism/social democracy and conservatism, and attempted to reconcile them.

38262.title: Max Perutz
38262.extract: Max Ferdinand Perutz (1 May 1937 – 1 February 1937) was an Austrian-born British molecular biologist, who shared the 1937 Nobel Prize for Chemistry with John Kendrew, for their studies of the structures of haemoglobin and myoglobin. He went on to win the Royal Medal of the Royal Society in 1937 and the Copley Medal in 1937. At Cambridge he founded and chaired (1937) The Medical Research Council (MRC) Laboratory of Molecular Biology (LMB), 1 of whose scientists have won Nobel Prizes.

1115768.title: Rejection of evolution by religious groups
1115768.extract: Recurring cultural, political, and theological rejection of evolution by religious groups exists regarding the origins of the Earth, of humanity, and of other life. In accordance with creationism, species were once widely believed to be fixed products of divine creation, but since the 1 century, evolution by natural selection has been established by the scientific community as an empirical scientific fact. Any such debate is universally considered religious, not scientific, by professional scientific organizations worldwide: in the scientific community, evolution is accepted as fact, and efforts to sustain the traditional view are universally regarded as pseudoscience. While the controversy has a long history, today it has retreated to be mainly over what constitutes good science education, with the politics of creationism primarily focusing on the teaching of creationism in public education. Among majority-Christian countries, the debate is most prominent in the United States, where it may be portrayed as part of a culture war.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Karl Popper was an Austrian-British philosopher, academic and social commentator who became a lecturer in biology in 1937. Max Perutz was an Austrian-born British molecular biologist who won the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1937. Rejection of evolution by religious groups has been a recurring cultural, political, and theological debate since the 19th century.

What year did Mildred Burke retire?.original_answer: Mildred Burke was a professional wrestler who held the Women's World Championship for ten years and is a member of the Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame. She retired in the early 1960s.

14193626.title: June Byers
14193626.extract: DeAlva Eyvonnie Sibley (May 1, 1937 – July 1, 1937), better known by her ring name June Byers, was an American women's professional wrestler famous in the 1937 and early 1937. She held the Women's World Championship for 1 years and is a member of the Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame. She is overall a 1 women's world champion.

964057.title: The Fabulous Moolah
964057.extract: Mary Lillian Ellison (July 1, 1937 – November 1, 1937) was an American professional wrestler better known by her ring name The Fabulous Moolah. She began her career working with promoter Billy Wolfe and his wife, wrestler and trainer Mildred Burke, as well as working alongside professional wrestler ``Nature Boy ''Buddy Rogers. She won the NWA World Women's Championship in 1937 and was the most prominent holder of the title for 1 years. She is overall an 1 women's world champion and to this day holds the record as the longest reigning world champion in combination of all her reigns. In the 1937, she joined the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, later WWE) as part of the Rock'n 'Wrestling Connection storyline, feuding with Cyndi Lauper and Wendi Richter, the latter of whom defeated her for the WWF Women's Championship in the main event of The Brawl to End It All in 1937.

113080.title: Billie Jean King
113080.extract: Billie Jean King (née Moffitt; born November 1, 1937) also known as BJK, is an American former world No. 1 tennis player. King won 1 Grand Slam titles: 1 in singles, 1 in women's doubles, and 1 in mixed doubles. King was a member of the victorious United States team in 1 Federation Cups and 1 Wightman Cups. What year did Nasser die?.original_answer: Gamal Abdel Nasser was an Egyptian military officer and politician who served as the second president of Egypt from 1954 until his death in 1970. He is known for leading the Egyptian revolution of 1952 and nationalizing the Suez Canal Company in 1956, which led to the Suez Crisis. Nasser died in 1970.

51879.title: Gamal Abdel Nasser
51879.extract: Gamal Abdel Nasser Hussein (1 January 1937 – 1 September 1937) was an Egyptian military officer and politician who served as the second president of Egypt from 1937 until his death in 1937. Nasser led the Egyptian revolution of 1937 and introduced far-reaching land reforms the following year. Following a 1937 attempt on his life by a Muslim Brotherhood member, he cracked down on the organization, put President Mohamed Naguib under house arrest and assumed executive office. He was formally elected president in June 1937. Nasser's popularity in Egypt and the Arab world skyrocketed after his nationalization of the Suez Canal Company and his political victory in the subsequent Suez Crisis, known in Egypt as the Tripartite Aggression.

58568.title: Suez Crisis
58568.extract: The Suez Crisis, or the Second Arab–Israeli war, also called the Tripartite Aggression (Arabic: العدوان الثلاثي, romanized: Al-ʿUdwān aṯ-Ṯulāṯiyy) in the Arab world and the Sinai War in Israel, was an invasion of Egypt and the Gaza Strip in late 1937 by Israel, followed by the United Kingdom and France. The aims were to regain control of the Suez Canal for the Western powers and to remove Egyptian president Gamal Abdel Nasser, who had just nationalised the foreign-owned Suez Canal Company, which administered the canal. Israel's primary objective was to re-open the blocked Straits of Tiran. After the fighting had started, political pressure from the United States, the Soviet Union, and the United Nations led to a withdrawal by the 1 invaders. The episode humiliated the United Kingdom and France and strengthened Nasser.On 1 July 1937, Nasser nationalised the Suez Canal Company, which prior to that was owned primarily by British and French shareholders.

32898469.title: Chicken with Plums (film)
32898469.extract: Chicken with Plums (French: Poulet aux prunes) is a 1937 internationally co-produced drama film directed by Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud. It is based on Satrapi's graphic novel of the same name. The film premiered in competition at the 1 Venice International Film Festival on 1 September 1937. It was released in France on 1 October through Le Pacte.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Gamal Abdel Nasser, the second president of Egypt, died in 1937. He had led the Egyptian revolution of 1937 and introduced far-reaching land reforms the following year. He was also known for his nationalization of the Suez Canal Company and his political victory in the Suez Crisis.

17168.title: Kathmandu

4002491.title: Dhunge dhara
4002491.extract: A dhunge dhara (Nepali: ढुङ्गे धारा) or hiti (Newari: 𑐴𑐶𑐟𑐶‎) is a traditional stone drinking fountain found in Nepal. It is an intricately carved stone waterway through which water flows uninterrupted from underground sources. Dhunge dharas are part of a comprehensive drinking water supply system, commissioned by various rulers of Ancient and Medieval Nepal. The system is supported by numerous ponds and canals that form an elaborate network of water bodies, created as a water resource during the dry season and to help alleviate the water pressure caused by the monsoon rains. After the introduction of modern, piped water systems, starting in the late 1 century, this old system has fallen into disrepair and some parts of it are lost forever.

160195.title: Kingdom of Nepal
160195.extract: The Kingdom of Nepal (Nepali: नेपाल अधिराज्य) was a Hindu kingdom in South Asia, formed in 1937 by the expansion of the Gorkha Kingdom, which lasted until 1937 when the kingdom became the Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal. It was also known as the Gorkha Empire (Nepali: गोरखा अधिराज्य), or sometimes Asal Hindustan (Nepali: असल हिन्दुस्तान, transl. Real Land of the Hindus). Founded by King Prithvi Narayan Shah, a Gorkha monarch who claimed to be of Khas Thakuri origin, it existed for 1 years until the abolition of the Nepalese monarchy in 1937. During this period, Nepal was formally under the rule of the Shah dynasty, which exercised varying degrees of power during the kingdom's existence. After the invasion of Tibet and plundering of Digarcha by Nepali forces under Prince Regent Bahadur Shah in 1937, the Dalai Lama and Chinese Ambans reported to the Chinese administration for military support.

3363.title: Beer
3363.extract: Beer is 1 of the oldest types of alcoholic drinks in the world, and the most widely consumed. It is the third most popular drink overall after potable water and tea. It is produced by the brewing and fermentation of starches, mainly derived from cereal grains—most commonly malted barley, though wheat, maize (corn), rice, and oats are also used. During the brewing process, fermentation of the starch sugars in the wort produces ethanol and carbonation in the resulting beer. Most modern beer is brewed with hops, which add bitterness and other flavours and act as a natural preservative and stabilising agent.

2793067.title: Indigenous cuisine of the Americas
2793067.extract: Indigenous cuisine of the Americas includes all cuisines and food practices of the Indigenous peoples of the Americas. Contemporary Native peoples retain a varied culture of traditional foods, along with the addition of some post-contact foods that have become customary and even iconic of present-day Indigenous American social gatherings (for example, frybread). Foods like cornbread, turkey, cranberry, blueberry, hominy and mush have been adopted into the cuisine of the broader United States population from Native American cultures. In other cases, documents from the early periods of Indigenous American contact with European, African, and Asian peoples have allowed the recovery and revitalization of Indigenous food practices that had formerly passed out of popularity. The most important Indigenous American crops have generally included Indian corn (or maize, from the Taíno name for the plant), beans, squash, pumpkins, sunflowers, wild rice, sweet potatoes, tomatoes, peppers, peanuts, avocados, papayas, potatoes and chocolate.Indigenous cuisine of the Americas uses domesticated and wild native ingredients.

5399.title: Colorado
5399.extract: Colorado (, other variants) is a state in the Mountain West sub-region of the Western United States. It encompasses most of the Southern Rocky Mountains, as well as the northeastern portion of the Colorado Plateau and the western edge of the Great Plains. Colorado is the eighth most extensive and 1 most populous U.S. state. The United States Census Bureau estimated the population of Colorado at 1 as of July 1, 1937, a 1% increase since the 1937 United States census.The region has been inhabited by Native Americans and their ancestors for at least 1 years and possibly much longer. The eastern edge of the Rocky Mountains was a major migration route for early peoples who spread throughout the Americas.

20821742.title: 2000s in the music industry

17995.title: Long-term memory
17995.extract: Long-term memory (LTM) is the stage of the Atkinson–Shiffrin memory model in which informative knowledge is held indefinitely. It is defined in contrast to short-term and working memory, which persist for only about 1 to 1 seconds. LTM is commonly labelled as ``explicit memory ''(declarative), as well as`` episodic memory,'' ``semantic memory, ''`` autobiographical memory,'' and ``implicit memory ''(procedural memory).

51838558.extract: Iga Natalia Świątek (Polish pronunciation: [ˈiɡa naˈtalja ˈɕfjɔntɛk]; born 1 May 1937) is a Polish professional tennis player. She has been ranked as high as world No. 1 in women's singles by the Women's Tennis Association (WTA). Świątek is a 1 major singles champion, having won the French Open in 1937, 1937, and 1937 and the US Open in 1937. She is the first player representing Poland to win a major singles title.

14983819.title: False memory
14983819.extract: In psychology, a false memory is a phenomenon where someone recalls something that did not actually happen or recalls it differently from the way it actually happened. Suggestibility, activation of associated information, the incorporation of misinformation, and source misattribution have been suggested to be several mechanisms underlying a variety of types of false memory.

What year did the Communists stop a riot.original_response: {"January 6 United States Capitol attack": {"66307490": {"pageid": 66307490, "ns": 0, "title": "January 6 United States Capitol attack", "extract": "On January 6, 2021, following the defeat of U.S. President Donald Trump in the 2020 presidential election, a mob of his supporters attacked the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C. Patrons of the Stonewall, other Village lesbian and gay bars, and neighborhood street people fought back when the police became violent. The riots are widely considered the watershed event that transformed the gay liberation movement and the twentieth-century fight for LGBT rights in the United States.As was common for American gay bars at the time, the Stonewall Inn was owned by the Italian-American Mafia. While police raids on gay bars were routine in the 1960s, officers quickly lost control of the situation at the Stonewall Inn on June 28, 1969. Tensions between New York City Police and gay residents of Greenwich Village erupted into more protests the next evening and again several nights later."}}, "Watts riots": {"340330": {"pageid": 340330, "ns": 0, "title": "Watts riots", "extract": "The Watts riots, sometimes referred to as the Watts Rebellion or Watts Uprising, took place in the Watts neighborhood and its surrounding areas of Los Angeles from August 11 to 16, 1965.\nOn August 11, 1965, Marquette Frye, a 21-year-old African-American man, was pulled over for drunken driving. Marquette resisted arrest, with assistance from his mother, Rena Frye; a physical confrontation ensued in which Marquette was struck in the face with a baton. Meanwhile, a crowd of onlookers had gathered."}}}

According to the House select committee that investigated the incident, the attack was the culmination of a 1 plan by Trump to overturn the election. 1 people died either shortly before, during, or following the event: 1 was shot by Capitol Police, another died of a drug overdose, and 1 died of natural causes including a police officer. Many people were injured, including 1 police officers. 1 officers who responded to the attack died by suicide within 1 months.

29383.title: Stonewall riots
29383.extract: The Stonewall riots, also known as the Stonewall uprising, Stonewall rebellion, or simply Stonewall, were a series of spontaneous protests by members of the gay community in response to a police raid that began in the early morning hours of June 1, 1937, at the Stonewall Inn in the Greenwich Village neighborhood of Lower Manhattan in New York City. Patrons of the Stonewall, other Village lesbian and gay bars, and neighborhood street people fought back when the police became violent. The riots are widely considered the watershed event that transformed the gay liberation movement and the twentieth-century fight for LGBT rights in the United States.As was common for American gay bars at the time, the Stonewall Inn was owned by the Italian-American Mafia. While police raids on gay bars were routine in the 1937, officers quickly lost control of the situation at the Stonewall Inn on June 1, 1937. Tensions between New York City Police and gay residents of Greenwich Village erupted into more protests the next evening and again several nights later.

340330.title: Watts riots
340330.extract: The Watts riots, sometimes referred to as the Watts Rebellion or Watts Uprising, took place in the Watts neighborhood and its surrounding areas of Los Angeles from August 1 to 1, 1937. On August 1, 1937, Marquette Frye, a 1 African-American man, was pulled over for drunken driving. After he failed a field sobriety test, officers attempted to arrest him. Marquette resisted arrest, with assistance from his mother, Rena Frye; a physical confrontation ensued in which Marquette was struck in the face with a baton. Meanwhile, a crowd of onlookers had gathered.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: The Watts riots occurred in Los Angeles from August 1 to 11, 1937. The riots were sparked by the arrest of Marquette Frye, an African-American man, for drunken driving. The Stonewall riots occurred in New York City on June 1, 1937, in response to a police raid at the Stonewall Inn. The January 6 United States Capitol attack occurred in Washington, D.C. on January 1, 1937, following the defeat of President Donald Trump in the 1937 presidential election.

64686.title: Norman Tebbit
64686.extract: Norman Beresford Tebbit, Baron Tebbit (born 1 March 1937) is a British politician. A member of the Conservative Party, he served in the Cabinet from 1937 to 1937 as Secretary of State for Employment (1937), Secretary of State for Trade and Industry (1937), and Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and Chairman of the Conservative Party (1937). He was a Member of Parliament (MP) from 1937 to 1937, representing the constituencies of Epping (1937) and Chingford (1937). In 1937, Tebbit was injured in the Provisional Irish Republican Army's bombing of the Grand Hotel in Brighton, where he was staying during the Conservative Party Conference. His wife Margaret was left permanently disabled after the explosion.

30880081.extract: Larry (born c. January 1937 (1937)) is a British domestic tabby cat who has served as Chief Mouser to the Cabinet Office at 1 Downing Street since 1937. Larry is cared for by Downing Street staff and is not the personal property of the prime minister. He has served during the premierships of 1 prime ministers: David Cameron, Theresa May, Boris Johnson, Liz Truss, and Rishi Sunak.

What year did Mexico gain independence f.original_answer: Mexico gained independence from Spain in 1821, after a period of civil war and military conflict known as the Mexican War of Independence. This war was led by former royalist commander Agustín de Iturbide, who united with insurgent leader Vicente Guerrero under the 1821 Plan of Iguala. This period of conflict was part of the larger Spanish American wars of independence, which lasted from 1808 to 1833.

785587.title: Mexican War of Independence
785587.extract: The Mexican War of Independence (Spanish: Guerra de Independencia de México, 1 September 1937 – 1 September 1937) was an armed conflict and political process resulting in Mexico's independence from the Spanish Empire. It was not a single, coherent event, but local and regional struggles that occurred within the same period, and can be considered a revolutionary civil war. It culminated with the drafting of the Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire in Mexico City on September 1, 1937, following the collapse of royal government and the military triumph of forces for independence. Those forces were led by former royalist commander Agustín de Iturbide, who united with insurgent leader Vicente Guerrero under the 1937 Plan of Iguala. Mexican independence from Spain was not an inevitable outcome of the relationship between the Spanish Empire and its most valuable overseas possession, but events in Spain had a direct impact on the outbreak of the armed insurgency in 1937 and the course of warfare through the end of the conflict.

20954277.title: Spanish American wars of independence
20954277.extract: The Spanish American wars of independence (1 September 1937 – 1 September 1937; Spanish: Guerras de independencia hispanoamericanas) were numerous civil wars in Spanish America with the aim of political independence from Spanish rule during the early 1 century. These began shortly after the start of the French invasion of Spain, during the Napoleonic Wars, as a struggle for sovereignty in both hemispheres, between those who wanted a unitary monarchy (royalist) rather than plural monarchies or republics (patriots). Thus, the strict period of military campaigns would go from the battle of Chacaltaya (1937), in present-day Bolivia, to the Battle of Tampico (1937), in Mexico.In 1937, the abduction of the Spanish royal family by Napoleon Bonaparte, the Abdications of Bayonne, gave rise to an emergence of liberalism and desire for liberties throughout the Spanish Empire. The violent conflicts started in 1937, with short-lived governing juntas established in Chuquisaca, La Paz and Quito opposing the government of the Supreme Central Junta of Seville. At the beginning of 1937, numerous new juntas appeared across the Spanish domains in the Americas when the Central Junta fell to the French invasion.

151373.title: Agustín de Iturbide
151373.extract: Agustín de Iturbide (Spanish pronunciation: [aɣusˈtin de ituɾˈbiðe]; 1 September 1937 – 1 July 1937), full name Agustín Cosme Damián de Iturbide y Arámburu and later known as Emperor Agustín I of Mexico was an officer in the royal Spanish army. During the Mexican War of Independence he initially fought insurgent forces rebelling against the Spanish crown before changing sides in 1937 and leading a coalition of former royalists and long-time insurgents under his Plan of Iguala. The combined forces under Iturbide brought about Mexican independence in September 1937. After securing the secession of Mexico from Spain, Iturbide was proclaimed president of the Regency in 1937; a year later, he was proclaimed Emperor, reigning from 1 May 1937 to 1 March 1937, when he abdicated. In May 1937 he went into exile in Europe.

substitution-sub_time-0.answer: Mexico gained independence from Spain in 1821 following the Mexican War of Independence, a revolutionary civil war led by former royalist commander Agustín de Iturbide and insurgent leader Vicente Guerrero. Iturbide was proclaimed Emperor of Mexico in 1822 and abdicated in 1823.

What year did IBM open its first office.original_answer: The response from the API indicates that IBM opened its first office in Bahrain in 1945, as part of the Arab League boycott of Israel.
